summary: Although awkward college student Todd Howard (Jason Bateman) is particularly adept at science, he's paying for school with an athletic scholarship that he will lose should he not fare well in an upcoming boxing tournament. Luckily for Todd, he has inherited the same family curse that once turned his cousin into a werewolf. As he transforms into the hairy, fanged, howling monster, he finds both his physical agility and his popularity skyrocketing -- but at what cost?

reviews.content: Is this a good follow up to Teen Wolf, not on your life, there are no jokes that I could find and the protagonist is not any fun, thus my rating of *1/2*...
I can't really hate a cash grab sequel movie that copies and paste the plot line of their first movie. Same story equals lazy sequel.
painful rip-off of the already dumb original

I generally don't mind rehash plotline for a sequel, give the people what they want.  But this is not just a rehash, it's practically cut and paste of the first movie.  Maybe they originally wanted Michael J. Fox to come back considering this is a college movie over High School but he smartly turned it down.  But I doubt his replacement Jason Bateman who plays Todd had a hard audition process as his dad was one of the producer.  Also, there are some annoying characters and the Dean who's pretty dumb to give a kid a sports scholarship without even knowing anything of the kid or looking if that sport was even part of his permitted record.  But it's not horrible either but it's the same story, with the same jokes and the same lesson.  It's not horrible, it's far from good.  It's just meh, and nepotism needs to end in Hollywood.

Nothing wrong with it but nothing really to look at. Not that great to listen to. It was just standard procedure. Terrible script. It just copied the first movie watering it down. The ending was horrible. I really recommend avoiding this cash-in travesty.
The worst sequel ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The first Teen Wolf is goofy but fun, so I went into this one expecting something similar, if a little less original. What I just watched is among the worst movies I've seen. Every line of dialogue is cringeworthy, not only in the way it is written but the way it is delivered. Every scene feels extremely awkward even though nothing really happens in them. The characters act so inconsistently and the acting is so stilted it is difficult to follow what's going on. It's as if the writers had as little idea as we do where the story is going and why the characters are acting the way they are. Relationships change drastically between scenes: one minute Todd (Jason Bateman), the teen wolf, is yelling furiously at his classmate Nicki (Estee Chandler), the next he's flirting with her like he hadn't just acted terrible and showed glowing red eyes. Halfway through, the movie just gives up on dialogue and dives into a 3 minute long montage of Bateman being a werewolf jerk. The wolf makeup looks like a mask for an aging chimp that the makers of Planet of the Apes threw away, managing to make the character less sympathetic and likable than he already is. The supporting cast are even worse, either yelling obnoxiously, staring at Bateman with creepy intensity, or doing nothing at all. Even though these characters may feel few, because they are so irrelevant, there are actually a lot of them, ever present and in the audience as the teen wolf dances stupidly and lip syncs terribly or gets pummeled in slow motion in the boxing ring. Boxing ends up being the center of the story, even more so than being a werewolf, and we are subjected to extended boxing sequences between characters we barely even know. What makes this worse is that college boxing isn't even a thing. That shows how much the writers were trying when they came up with this one. Eventually they stoop to a fart joke. Well, not even a joke. It's just a fart. But it's funny and it proves to be the highlight of the movie.
In defense of teen wolf too, it's not that bad. I'm almost tempted to call it good

A cheesy retread of the original. There's a bit of fun too have in it. But it's just a lesser carbon copy of the first. It should've just done it's own thing, and it could've been at least okay. It really jumps the shark with that musical sequence...

what a silly, harmless, movie that has some sort of campy, 80's college feel....like revenge of the nerds. Not an oscar, just a ridiculously, goof ball get away. Some movies are just fun to poke fun of, and thats worth a whole lotta stars.
A cheesy below par sequel to the cheesy only slightly above par original.
This has to be one of the worst films ever made. Singing werewolf party, really?

Bateman is an irritating bore but the direction is decent and the soundtrack is solid. Estee Chandler is good as the love interest but the rest of the actors seem totally bored or are just phoning it in. It's not the original but it has a zany charm that I find endearing.
worst soundtrack of any film...ever

i just realized that this teen wolf is jason bateman?
either way...don't bother with this one.   unless is on right after the first Teen Wolf...which is what happened to me.

This one might not be completely on par with the original. However Teen Wolf Too does has something going for it. First of all the inescapable magic of the Eighties. Then there is the incredibly charming Jason Bateman. On top of it all one of the highlights in the film is the study montage with song Send me an angel. All of it combined will give you enough to be satisfied.

I'm not sure what's going on with the movies title here, is that suppose to be a clever play on words or something? or maybe just a quirky way of showing its a sequel without using a boring number 2. Anyway this time around we follow the lycanthropic antics of Scott Howard's cousin Todd.

The basic story for this movie is also the basic problem...its exactly the flippin' same. The original movie saw Scott battle with his affliction in high school, dealing with puberty, love, girls, bullies, friends, grades and of course the main issue of his basketball team. In this story Todd has just gotten into his university and has to deal with being a young adult, love, girls, bullies, friends, grades and the main issue of his boxing team. The difference here being Todd doesn't know he's a werewolf and has his first 'wolf-out' occurrence in his new uni surroundings conveniently.

OK so they are pretty much rehashing the first movie...could still be good. Thing is the plot doesn't really add up and is full of blatant idea pinching from the first movie. First off the coach on this uni boxing team is the same coach from Scott's basketball team in high school in the first film! He is actually suppose to be the same person! How would this high school coach now be the coach in this uni at the exact time when Scott's cousin is there? The answer to that is this coach got Todd a full athletic scholarship based on the hopes that Todd is also a werewolf and will turn the uni boxing team into champs. What??!! is that for real?! OK he could help with the scholarship for Todd but how did he manage to become the boxing coach at the same time?? OK OK breathe...

That's one major nonsensical plot point, another is why Scott's father Harold (James Hampton back again) is here. He lives in Beacon Town, Nebraska according to my sources, Todd's university is Hamilton which in reality is located in Colorado (I'm guessing the same for the movie). Now those two states are connected admittedly so its possible these two locations could be close (or not)...but why would Scott's dad be even in this story? Why would he be hanging around and watching the final boxing match? is he staying in a motel somewhere?

Another point that does tend to spring to mind when you watch is why the hell these people haven't turned into mega rich celebrities by now with there impressive family gift. I would of thought by now the science world would be all over them wanting to learn from them, take samples, run tests etc...they'd be on TV, in movies, in papers etc...a new form of humanoid! The fact that Harold flaunts his lycanthropy without a care in the world you'd think many would know by now, he's basically exposing himself. Yet the fact when people do see him as a werewolf they are still shocked...kinda says to me the Howard's haven't come out of the werewolf closet yet. Am I being too picky here? yeah maybe but come on!

The other gaping issues I have with the movie is the continuity or lack of...or shambolic attempt at. OK so I already told you that the coach was suppose to be the same character from the first movie, unfortunately they cast someone who obviously doesn't look like the original guy plus they try to copy the original guys hair and fail. Next up is the classic character of Styles, he's back...but played by someone else. Unfortunately and with great wisdom they cast a clearly much younger person to play Styles plus this guy looks totally and utterly nothing like the original character. Next is John 'Gomez' Astin as the Dean of the university, an original character...oops no, they make him exactly the same character as Principal Thorne in the original movie with the exact same motives. The only proper continuity is Mark Holton as Chubby...wait...did they actually have a musical number in this?

So yeah there are a lot of problems with this movie, glaring easy to spot problems, but its not all bad. They do get the werewolf makeup and prosthetics correct which is nice to see, they do look very close to the original although not quite as good. Jason Bateman does actually fit the role well, he is a likable guy and he does look kinda similar to Fox truth be told, you could believe they are related. That (now) entire cliched 80's frat house vibe is strong here naturally but that's a rose-tinted retro plus point, also check out all the cute 80's girls in their 80's fashions (God I miss the 80's). Lastly the boxing finale is reasonably exciting, it looks OK and relatively realistic, it does just about give you the buzz needed in the end.

In short this movie can't compare to the original in any way. The original had that low budget appeal, a cracking 80's score, some cheeky semi-adult angles and charismatic characters. This movie merely regurgitates the lot but its watered down to appeal to more people. The score doesn't have the same emotional force behind it, the characters are a shadow of their former selves, the new characters are cheap rip-offs of the previous ones and they literately copy the original plot almost scene for scene. One fatal mistake being this time they actually make the main hero character unlikable by the midway point. He becomes such a showboating show off as the wolf and clearly becomes an asshole, where as Scott in the original movie was always likable even with his inflated ego.

Despite all that its still an enjoyable movie I can't deny, maybe its because I grew up with these movies as a kid makes me biased. Even though its a bad sequel, if you try not to think about the superior original and take it as it is, you do have an easy going fun piece of trashy 80's trash.

Amazing film. Jason Bateman is at the peak of his game for this one folks. He takes the hand off from Michael J Fox and just bodies this who genre. my favorite part is when he catches a Frisbee with his bare mouth like a pup pup. My dude JB is a boxer in this peice and i know one human I would prefer not to be...the guy boxing him. Cause homeboy is vicious with the gloves. and he is hairy as heck so it's kind of gross to be in close combat like that. Anyhow, check out this film. so many loose ends are tied up from the first Teen Wolf. You won't be disappointed unless you are a total dingus who doesn't like good cinema. And if that is the case then why are you even reading this review??

Jason Bateman takes the lead in the abysmal sequel Teen Wolf Too.  It pretty much follows the same formula as the first film; substituting college for high school and boxing for basketball.  But the boxing motif is incredible stupid and makes no damned sense.  And, Bateman just doesn't have what it takes to make this garbage work.  An incompetent mess, Teen Wolf Too tries too hard to recreate the charm of the first film and ends up looking foolish.
Crappy hack sequel that kills any chance of a franchise the first film had. A total waste of time.
Basically the same movie as the first one made in 1985 but with a different lead male actor (Jason Bateman) and a different sport: Boxing instead of Basketball.
What a weak and boring movie with no joy to it and the comedy is god damn awful, the end fight to me went on and in for ever just like transformers 2.
one of the worst sequels I have ever seen.

Teen Wolf Too is a pathetic rehash of an entertaining predecessor which wastes the talents of Jason Bateman in his film debut who stands as the only thing holding the film up as it plunders through pathetic attempts at humour, a plot predictable because it was all there in Teen Wolf and plotting which suffers through terrible boxing scenes that completely ignore the concepts of what makes boxing a real sport. Teen Wolf Too jumped the shark after Teen Wolf intentionally came close to doing it many times but evading it through the natural comedic charm of its wolf theme. Now it's all dead, and not coming back from the dead like an undead werewolf.
same plot as original this movie sucks

Todd Howard thinks that the family curse has finally skipped a generation until it lands right on his face in TEEN WOLF TOO! Christopher Leitch leaves nothing to chance in this unnecessary sequel, trying his best to recreate the same successes of the first film with very little variance. Jason Bateman is much better than the film deserves, and actually gives a sharp and funny performance despite the mediocre production. We see the same progression in Todd as we had scene before with Michael J. Fox's Scott, where both characters turn on their friends and become real jerks after getting a taste of teenage popularity. The only difference here is that Todd is now playing for the college boxing team rather than a high school basketball team. When topped off with the rather ugly make-up effects, Jason Bateman looks more like a disfigured cat than he ever does a wolf. Paul Sand, Mark Holton, and James Hampton make appearances from the original, with John Astin and Kim Darby joining the cast.
it knocked me for a loop haha

Wretched sequel where the plot is almost a carbon copy of the original.  Script likely written for Michael J Fox as many of his friends and even his dad from the original appear.  He wisely took a pass on this one.
ouch everything felt so wrong in this movie ^^)V,,

I get making a sequel to the very popular Teen Wolf and I'm happy that while they replaced the main actor, he wasn't the same character but there is just too much wrong with this film to make it enjoyable. Though I'm not quite sure why much of the cast from the first film was included in this sequel. They weren't needed and while I could have accepted one (Mark Holton as Chubby), Uncle Harold, Coach Finstock and even Stiles (who is played by a different actor for some reason) don't need to be in this film.
But that's not what truly makes this film a bummer.  Sure it wasn't likely going to be as good as the first film but did it have to be practically the same film? High School turns into College, basketball turns into boxing, and M. J. Fox turns into J. Bateman but it's otherwise the same damn film. The big difference is this one (other than being a blatant copy) doesn't have the charm of the first film and instead fills the screen with Revenge of the Nerds antics. Now I like Revenge of the Nerds and Animal House as much as the next guy but that wasn't what Teen Wolf was about.  
Teen Wolf Too lacks the heart of the original and instead fills the gaps with garbage jokes and antics. I'm surprised there wasn't a hairy palm joke to be honest.

Sequel to Teen Wolf is not the film that it could have been. This film is poorly constructed and has a recycled plot from the first one with a different lead actor and setting. The film had an interesting idea for its plot, but the filmmakers seem to be going through the motions and don't have anything exciting to offer. The film is just dull, boring and stupid. The fact that Michael J. Fox is absent from the film makes this a bland affair. There's really nothing new going on here, and Teen Wolf Too is just a poor sequel to a comedy horror classic. The result on-screen is a film that just doesn't have anything interesting. This film just tries to cash in on the success of the original, and it does it very poorly. This film was horrible, and doesn't have the magic the first one had. The first one was cheesy, but it was lots of fun from start to finish. However this film is just too predictable, and add to that a bad cast, a poorly written script that just isn't interesting, and you have a bad film. Stick with the original, although cheesy, imperfect and corny at times, it was a fun film to watch. This, on the other hand is just a failed attempt at building on the original by using old ideas instead of using something new. This is just a tiresome film that isn't worth your time. Jason Batman has done much better than this, and he does what he can with such a poor script, but ultimately it ends up being a dire, predictable and boring film that you just don't care about. Watch the original Teen Wolf instead; this film is basically a rehash of ideas previously explored in the first film. You're not missing much by not watching this.

Just rehashed material from the first one. A movie about a high school basketball player becoming popular when he turns into a werewolf spawns a sequel about his cousin who's a college boxer. Worst of all, the movie even tried to replace Styles.
Yuck.  While the first was silly fun, this is an unfunny slog.  Bad news all around.
Still bad funny but just...worse.

Granted  this  is  not  the  hit  the  first  one  was  but  still  is  a  decent  movie. Jason  Bateman  plays  the  cousin  of  Scott  Howard  who  is  in  college  and  thinks  he  skipped  a  generation  of  not  being  a  werewolf  but  ends  up  neing  one.  By  no  means  is  this  a  classic  like  the  first  but  I  still  enjoyed  watching  it.  Far  from  being  great  but  not  completely  bad  neither.
5/26/2016: pretty cheesy, but still somewhat entertaining.
oh wow...I was really excited to see this...and...yeah...the best part about it is seeing an 18 year old Jason Bateman
not as good as the first but ok
Holy Shit, this film is so bad I cant even be bothered to finish this rev............
not as good as the first
I love teen wolf but this was laughable, spiderman 3 laughable.

I had almost forgotten how awful this movie is!  It follows the same story pattern as the first, only it forgot to be funny and entertaining.  This is one movie that deserves to be lost in the 80's and forgotten.

(* 1/2): [img]http://images.rottentomatoes.com/images/user/icons/icon13.gif[/img]

It didn't annoy me as much as the first film, but this film is not all that fun or entertaining.  A forgettable film.

Jason Bateman takes on the role of Teen Wolf (as the original's cousin actually) when Michale J. Fox got a real career following the success of Back to the Future.  This movie is essentially just a complete rehash, plot and all, of the first film.  Minor changes to characters, places, and events can't really hide the fact that nothing you didn't already see happens here.  Instead of high school it's college, instead of basketball it's the college boxing team (?)...other than that it really is just the same lame movie all over again.
As bad as they come. Even diehard Jason Bateman fans would be hard-pressed to find many positives about this unnecessary and cut rate sequel.
tries to recreate the same magic from the first film, without realizing why the first film was so good.
tries to recreate the same magic from the first film, without realizing why the first film was so good.
this film was terrible. It had no time frame reference so i didn't know what was going on. it had charm or style like the first film. this was a bad film
This one sucked though
Basically the same storyline as the first movie, with the actor who was the dad in the first movie now playing the uncle. Different actor for the same character of Stiles. Very, very bad sequel.
just not the same. yawn
it's a teen horror film of all time.

I can't understand why they would even think about making a sequel to the Teen Wolf movie. This movie was rubbish and very boring. I actually liked Teen Wolf very much when I was younger, Teen Wolf Too doesn't have the same qualities at all. It just seems like they have straight out copied the plot from the first movie and changed a few things, this can never make a movie succesful. Do not waste your time like I did by watching this movie.
The effects were not that great and the story moved way to fast. Plus, the story was not that great.
A film that never should have been made. Why make an even more awful sequel to an awful first.
The return of the wolf sees the cousin from the first one enter college to show off something he has never used before in a boxing ring. Not a very good sequel
Sorry Bateman, the movie was horrible.

A sequel was a really bad idea but that is the entertainment industry; always trying to cash in at any cost.  The plot is almost exactly as the 1st "Teen Wolf"(as I mentioned in my previous review).  Dorky lead that becomes a popular jerk, troublesome friend trying to cash in and get popular, fat friend with hidden talent, nerdy yet sorta cute brunette, and a pretty, blonde, bitchy, bimbo that has only her looks to offer.  Oh and a sports event to prove that it not the wolf but the man who overcomes.
a totally unnecesary sequel
Not as entertaining as the first movie, but most sequels aren't as good as the original.  It was fun to watch the wolf sing and dance though.

Jason Bateman (son of the producer!) plays Michael J. Fox's cousin in a dire sequel to the less-than-great original.  There's a song and dance routine that rips off Ferris Bueller, and that's the film's most original moment.  It was written by Tim Kring, who went on to create the television series Heroes.  Perhaps that explains why Heroes became such a steamer.

Just horrible.
Made me itch while watching this trash
One of the worst movies of the 80s, it's not a good comedy, not a good werewolf movie, and not a good sequel.  What is good about it?  The music maybe?  Not much...
Got to love it on principal coz of the first film!
Terrible sequel! It was funny to see  a vintage Jason Bateman but it bares no resemblance to the original film

You can tell they knocked this one up in a hurry. Worth watching for Batemen time, and added value of a singalong with extended dancing, which made me laugh, cry, cringe: the whole nine yards! 

It's funny how 1987/88 were the Lamest years for style in the 80s, as it really shows in the costumes!
An awful sequel to a classic original..
A cheesy sequel, but I loved Jason Bateman in this.
The original wasn't fantastic, but still pretty good. This one isn't even decent.
Oh Jason Bateman, I would buy all of your Teen Beats.
I am a Jason Bateman fan but this is a pretty lame movie, if you want to see him in something much better watch Extract or the tv series Arrested Development.
Just about acceptable until the wolf appears, after that it becomes a ludicrous sequel offering nothing new and simply replacing the basketball with boxing.

Wow, I'd completely forgot about this terrible sequel and wouldn't even review it had I not just reviewed the original. A complete waste of time, void of originality, laughs and lacking the charisma of Michael J. Fox.

My favourite part is easily this:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IfA2MuUJDyI

But that's in "Teen Wolf" 1 whereas this film sucked.

Half a star for Scott's Dad though!

What concept could be better than a teenage wolfman boxing?  Please, someone give the guy who came up with this concept a medal.  This is what a sports film should be, especially a boxing one.  Who needs Rocky or Raging Bull when Teen Wolf Too knocks them both out cold!

Teen Wolf Too (1987) -- [2.0] -- The charm that young Jason Bateman exhibited on television's "The Hogan Family" is absent here, stifled by a painfully insipid script and direct-to-video production values. I can't think of another movie sequel that so closely mimics its predecessor. The only differences between the two movies are the lead actor and the sport they play. The film even returns several inconsequential supporting characters, whether they're played by the same actor or not. It's odd and frustrating to watch a movie where the filmmakers were clearly terrified of straying from a mediocre formula. It makes "Teen Wolf Too" worse than a bad movie -- it's punishment.

This movie was released only two years after the original, ignoring the previous movie, then replicating the exact same storyline, except having it happen in college with wrestling...they also removed Michael J. Fox and dropped the quality of humour and characters...why was this even made?
hah. this movie is so crazy.

Um... is this a joke?  A prank pulled on the people of America?  A ruse?  Because this is the same movie as the first one.  Every beat is the same.  This is a joke of a sequel due to it not being anything more than the exact same movie but they swapped out basketball for boxing.  What a brilliant idea!  Let put a young man in the ring with a werewolf and have them fight.  What could go wrong?
This Movie was ok but the first one was alot better.

Its not like the original Teen Wolf was any good (I thought it flopped) so I don't think that it warrented a sequel.  Teen Wolf Too is pretty 2nd rate even down to the casting of Jason Bateman who is a 2nd rate Micheal J Fox.  Annoyingly bad especially the music number where Bateman does his rendition of Do you Love Me.  It just makes me want to poke out my fucking eyes & ears w/ a sharp instrument.
What a wasted opportunity. First film is an 80's classic but this just copies the storyline and changed a few characters. Shame as Jason Bateman has turned out to be a comic genius!
The same exact movie as the first, except the first was way better (not in a good way). Like teh first though, the lead actor, Jason Bateman in this one, at least shows some charisma.

This is one of the most horrible sequals. Jason Bateman must be ashamed of this movie. It follows every exact plot point as Teen Wolf. It brings back Stiles and the coach except they are being played by different actors. And why is Michael J Fox's dad from the first movie taking care of Bateman's character.
Haven't seen this for a long while but from what I remember it wasn't a patch on the original with Michael J Fox.

AKA: The Remake; that is virtually what this film is. We have Scott's cousin now going through the heritage bought down by his family. He comes to College under a boxing scholarship, thanks to Scott's basketball coach, turned boxing coach. 
Jason Batemen, having become a success with The Hogan Family as bought in with hopes of a similar success with the first film. This is not the case, the film has lost many of its appeal. 
The acting is thinly done well. Batemen plays his role well, but its the script that is wrong. 
The film starts off one way and during the middle seems to lose itself and just becomes a jumbled mess. 

The music isn't as good, except with one song. The boxing matches are the worse ever directed. The cliches set forth in this film are so ridiculous is hilarious. I watched this film again after almost 10 years since the last time I saw it and I still felt the same way I did long ago.
2 out of 5 stars
SÃ¥ og sei den samme filmen som den fusste va, barre dÃ¥rligare i alle ledd.
Pretty bad, but really, so was Teen Wolf. You had no right to expect anything else. Yay 80s!
"You can't go through life as a wolf and expect it to solve all your problems."
I don't think it was as good as the first one but it was a very enjoyable film. :)
No where near as good as the first, but it wasn't bad.
wow - this is a really awful movie. I thought I'd have a few laughs at the ridiculousness of the whole boxing-werewolf scenario, but it wasn't even good enough for that.
not as good as the first
4/10. Basically a rip off of the first. Nothing new here, same gags, same story except basket ball is swapped for boxing. Pretty forgetable really.
sorry, jason bateman...

Okay, if the number 2, or any reference to the number 2, is a part of the movie's title, it's a safe bet it never should have been made. 
Just wait for the remake, er, I mean "re-imaging."

The original Teen Wolf isn't that great a film, it really is only the combined love of Michael J Fox and general nostalgia for nutty 80s films that keep it's memory alive...this sequel struggles to say the least. It's not that Jason Bateman is bad in it, it's just that everything else around him is either a direct rip-off of the original or a an average at best alternative. There is a "study montage" scene for crying out loud.
Haven't seen this for a long while but from what I remember it wasn't a patch on the original with Michael J Fox.
Not bad for a sequel, tries to repeat the same jokes as the first one.
Really lame compared to the first one.
Wow how terrible. It takes all the bad in Teen Wolf and none of the good.
Crap sequel. Or rehash, whatever you want to call it.

If you have ever wondered what a comedy that doesn't make you laugh is like, well then check this one out.  Its not even bad funny (like Conan the Barbarian, etc.) it is just straight up awful.  Stick with the M.J. Fox original and leave this one in the bargin bin.
it was ok for what it was...the first was better!

- on dvd -
I don't actually think the first Teen Wolf movie is all that great. But I don't think this one is much worse. It's enjoyable at least with some cool moments. This is like the only Jason Bateman movie I've ever seen were he is in the lead role. I think you can see why he doesn't get many starring roles plus you can see why his career slowed down for about 15 years after this movie. At least he was saved by Arrested Development. Pretty funny seeing Gomez from the original Adams Family in this movie. Plus a lot of familiar looking television actors. I'm pretty sure that Stiles is not the original Stiles too. Enjoyable but lame.
I liked this sequel but hated that the original stiles was played by soem other dude. But , at least, the original actor who played chubby was back.
VERY WEAK IF U COMPARE IT WITH THE 1ST ONE

The phenomenon of Teen Wolf refused to die. Following 1985's original film, there was an animated series, and then Teen Wolf Too. Michael J. Fox refused to return (citing the discomfort of the make-up as a factor), and so producer Kent Bateman turned to his own son, Jason (now of Arrested Development fame) to step in. You have to feel for poor Jason. He gamely gives it his best, but he's working with such an awful script that, despite his best efforts, the film is kind of a disaster. A lot of the characters return from the first film (some played by different actors) in an attempt to connect this sequel to the first film (Bateman plays the cousin of Michael J Fox's character), but most of the film doesn't work. It follows exactly the same plot as the previous film, but with school replaced with college and basketball replaced with boxing. It's worth watching though for a really bizarre song and dance sequence halfway through, with Bateman in full wolf get-up. Odd
I expected nothing and I got less than that.

Jason Bateman is my favorite actor in the world but this is just silly.  No wonder he got almost no work after this before being revived by Arrested Development.  The movie was fun to watch to make fun of but thats about it.

Just rehashed material from the first one. A movie about a high school basketball player becoming popular when he turns into a werewolf spawns a sequel about his cousin who's a college boxer. Worst of all, the movie even tried to replace Styles.

it was pretty good
i like scott better though.
hehe
So bad!  You have to love it!
I wasn't a fan of the first Teen Wolf, but this movie was just horrible, at least the first one had Michael J. Fox!
Loved the first one but this one sucks!

Un film pas aussi bon que le premier, restait culte pour le dessin annimé et Michael J Fox.
L'histoire laisse présager que  cette suite devait surement reprendre le caractére de Fox, mais elle a subit des changements perdant de son mordant. On regarde et on rigolait de ces vieilles années...

One of the worst sequels. You know a sequel sucks when the main character of the first is long gone and you're left with his cousin. What is this a sitcom? Stiles is played by another guy who clearly isn't Jerry Levine. About the only thing that you have to link this to the original is the Dad and Mark Holton. Teen Wolf is back, except this time the curse has fallen upon Michael J. Fox's cousin, played by a young Jason Bateman.  There is no point explaining the plot, because if you have seen the first film, then you have seen this one.  That's right, everything is this film is exactly what you saw in the first.  At first Bateman is afraid of the curse, but then he embraces it and becomes the popular kid in school, and joins the boxing team.  While doing this he loses his friends and the girl he likes, only to learn of his mistakes and stop being the wolf in the final match.  Change the basketball match to a boxing match, and shift around a few faces (Though not all of them, as the friends from the first film are back, playing the exact same "I feel ignored now" friends) and you have a complete and unnecessary rehash of the first film.  On top of it all though, this film decided to throw away all the laughs and charm of the first film, and instead added a bad after school special feel to it.  In the end what you have is a horribly boring deja vu experience that you will be counting down the clock for its finale.  I'm going to give it one star just because it at least had the cliche 80's musical montage in the middle of it, but even that wasn't done very well.  Bateman, what were you thinking? Oh yeah... $!
not as good as the 1st one ! but still a classic !

The only surprise on offer here is that it took as long as two years to bash out a cash-in sequel that copies from the original as lazily as this one. 'Teen Wolf' is an underrated corker and it causes me physical pain to watch this leaden hack job rehash that film's entire plot -ÂÂ and I mean the ENTIRE plot -ÂÂ with a slavish desperation that stops just short of editing in footage from its template movie. The original has charm, engaging characters, an excellent soundtrack, Michael J. Fox, and it's very, very funny. This sequel has none of that, plus a lot of other things it should have but doesn't. Jason Bateman is saddled with make-up that makes him look like Cornelius from 'Planet of the Apes' has had a nasty run-in with a belt sander, while the recasting of two major characters from the first film (Finstock and Stiles) is just rubbing salt in the wound. The only thing to be said in its favour is that it's better than the appalling cartoon series. But so what?

The brilliant sequel to Teen Wolf peels back the foreskin of American life and finds exactly what you'd expect: loneliness, pain, hypocrisy, jealousy, infidelity, and murder. Using his standard vignettes with a cast of dozens, the film (thankfully) never works toward a plot resolution, content instead with behavior; how we talk, how we deal with pain and loss, and how, just as often, we use tragic circumstances to justify the past. From Jason Bateman  to Mark Holton, the cast shines from start to finish, refusing to bow to cheap sentiment or manipulation. And the closing scene? Not God's wrath, silly boy, but a quick jolt to remind us that our "concerns," seemingly all-consuming and so damned important, are little more than neuroses that keep us scared to death of each other. Whether we live or die, succeed or fail, is just pure randomness, despite our all-too-American sense of invulnerability.

I give it four, because I'm a Jason Bateman fan, at that. But seriously, the "sequel" to the original Teen Wolf is actually just a remake, if you replace the words high school with college, and basketball with boxing. Stiles also magically changes races in between films and sports a dated-as-hell mullet. Good for a laugh, but it's Bateman's and Chandler's chemistry that really make a watch worthwhile.

It sure is hard to make a sequel that could be considered good enough to stand next to the 1985 cult classic, "Teen Wolf", starring Michael J. Fox. So do they even try? Not really. In fact, they pretty much remake the first one but use a different setting, some new characters, and a different sport for the Wolf to exceed at. Don't get the wrong idea though - "Teen Wolf Too" certainly pleases me. With knockout performances by Jason Bateman and John Astin, the second installment in the "Wolf" series is not better than the first, but it is definitely a respectable follow-up. Now if only Paramount Studios would spit up the money to produce a "Teen Wolf 3".
